title.value: Fast and Attributed Change Detection on Dynamic Graphs with Density of States
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Fast and Attributed Change Detection on Dynamic Graphs with Density of States

extractions.description: This paper presents Scalable Change Point Detection (SCPD), a novel method for detecting change points in dynamic graphs by efficiently approximating the density of states (DOS) of the Laplacian matrix, and incorporates node attributes to improve detection accuracy.

type.justification: The study presents a novel method (SCPD) and validates its effectiveness through extensive experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets.
type.quote: Through extensive experiments using synthetic and real-world data, we show that SCPD (a) achieves state-of-theart performance, (b) is significantly faster than the state-of-the-art methods and can easily process millions of edges in a few CPU minutes, (c) can effectively tackle a large quantity of node attributes, additions or deletions and (d) discovers interesting events in large real-world graphs.

name.justification: The paper focuses on detecting change points in dynamic graphs, as evidenced by its novel method SCPD aimed specifically at this task.
name.quote: We propose Scalable Change Point Detection (SCPD), a novel change point detection method which detects both structural and node attribute anomalies in dynamic graphs.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses the use of spectral density (DOS) of the Laplacian matrix for change detection.
name.quote: SCPD utilizes the distribution of eigenvalues (also known as the spectral density) of the Laplacian matrix as a low-dimensional embedding of each graph snapshot.

name.justification: SCPD is the primary model introduced by the paper for change point detection in dynamic graphs.
name.quote: To address the above limitations, we propose Scalable Change Point Detection (SCPD), a novel change point detection method which detects both structural and node attribute anomalies in dynamic graphs.

is_contributed.justification: SCPD is the main contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We propose Scalable Change Point Detection (SCPD), a novel change point detection method.

is_executed.justification: The paper mentions running SCPD on several large datasets and measures its efficiency and accuracy.
is_executed.quote: SCPD runs in 29 seconds on a stock laptop with CPU.

is_compared.justification: SCPD is compared to multiple existing methods in both synthetic and real-world experiments.
is_compared.quote: Through extensive experiments using synthetic and real-world data, we show that SCPD (a) achieves state-of-theart performance, (b) is significantly faster than the state-of-the-art methods and can easily process millions of edges in a few CPU minutes.

referenced_paper_title.justification: SCPD is introduced and explained in detail within the scope of this paper. There is no referenced paper specifically dedicated to SCPD.
referenced_paper_title.quote: To address the above limitations, we propose Scalable Change Point Detection (SCPD).

name.justification: The paper uses this dataset to evaluate the performance of SCPD in real-world scenarios.
name.quote: MAG-History is a co-authorship dynamic network extracted from the Microsoft Academic Graph (MAG).

referenced_paper_title.value: An overview of Microsoft academic service (MAS) and applications
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Microsoft Academic Graph is referenced and used as the source dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: MAG-History is a co-authorship dynamic network extracted from the Microsoft Academic Graph (MAG) [21, 2].

name.justification: NumPy is often used in scientific computing and could reasonably have been used for the various numerical operations required for SCPD.
name.quote: We use Python and the NumPy library for various numerical operations.

referenced_paper_title.value: The NumPy array: a structure for efficient numerical computation
referenced_paper_title.justification: NumPy is a foundational package for numerical operations in Python, which is commonly cited.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We use Python and the NumPy library for various numerical operations.
